case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. K. Habibullah

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 557 and 558 of 1960 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 557 and 558 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 10, 1957,

facts.text: Appeals were from the judgment and order dated April 10, 1957, of the Madras High Court in W.P. No. 952 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 10, 1957, of the Madras High Court in W.P. No. 952 of 1955. N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellants. Thiagarajan, for the respondent. 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 24, 1962 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-One S. K. Mohideen-hereinafter referred to as the assessee-

facts.text: S. K. Mohideen was a partner in Messrs. Dinshaw and Co. and Messrs. Palanippa Chettiar and Co.

anchor.surface_text: One S. K. Mohideen-hereinafter referred to as the assessee-was a partner in two firms-Messrs. Dinshaw and Co. and Messrs. Palanippa Chettiar and Co. The firms were registered under the Indian Income Tax Act.

facts.text: The firms were registered under the Indian Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The firms were registered under the Indian Income Tax Act. The assessee submitted returns of his income and incorporated therein the estimated share of his losses in the two firms at Rs. 20,000/- and Rs. 10,000/-

facts.text: Assessee submitted returns for assessment year 1946-47 with estimated losses of Rs. 20,000/- in Dinshaw and Rs. 10,000/- in Palanippa.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee submitted returns of his income and incorporated therein the estimated share of his losses in the two firms at Rs. 20,000/- and Rs. 10,000/- for the assessment year 1946-47 and at Rs. nil and Rs. 12,436/- for the assessment year 1947-48.

facts.text: Assessee submitted returns for assessment year 1947-48 with estimated losses of Rs. nil in Dinshaw and Rs. 12,436/- in Palanippa.

anchor.surface_text: for the assessment year 1946-47 and at Rs. nil and Rs. 12,436/- for the assessment year 1947-48. The Income-tax Officer, V. Circle, Madras companypleted the assessment for the two years on February 20, 1950

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, V Circle, Madras completed assessments for 1946-47 and 1947-48 on February 20, 1950, adopting assessee's estimates but subject to revision.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, V. Circle, Madras companypleted the assessment for the two years on February 20, 1950 after adopting the estimates furnished by the assessee, but he made a numbere that the losses accepted were subject to revision on ascertainment of companyrect particulars.

facts.text: Assessment of Messrs. Dinshaw Co. for 1946-47 and 1947-48 completed on October 31, 1950 by ITO II Circle, Madras; assessee's share of losses Rs. 15,839/- and Rs. 1,046/- respectively.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment of Messrs. Dinshaw Co, for the years 1946-47 and 1947-48 was companypleted on October 31, 1950 by the Income-tax officer II Circle, Madrass and the proportionate share of the assessee for the losses was companyputed for the two years at Rs. 15,839/- and Rs. 1,046/- respectively.

facts.text: Assessment of Messrs. Palanippa Chettiar Co. for 1947-48 completed on June 30, 1951 by ITO Special Circle; assessee's share of loss Rs. 2,009/-

anchor.surface_text: Assessment of Messrs. Palaniappa Chettiar Co. for 1947-48 was companypleted by the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle on June 30, 1951 and the share of the assessee in the loss suffered by that firm was companyputed at Rs. 2,009/-.

facts.text: ITO V Circle issued notices on May 4, 1953 to show cause why assessments should not be rectified under s.35.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of intimation of the orders passed in the assessment of the two firms, the Income-tax officer, V Circle, Madras issued on May 4, 1953 numberices to show cause why the assessments of the asessee, for the years 1946-47 and 1947-48 should number be rectified under s. 35 of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Assessee wrote to ITO on March 24, 1954 stating no objection to completing assessments according to law.

anchor.surface_text: On March 24, 1954, the assessee wrote to the Income-tax Officer stating This is to inform you that I have numberobjection in companypleting the assessments of the previous years in accordance with law.

facts.text: ITO revised assessments on March 27, 1954 taking into account shares from firm assessments.

anchor.surface_text: On March 27, 1954, the Income-tax officer revised the assessment of the assessee in respect of the two years after taking into account the share of the losses as companyputed in the assessments of the two firms.

facts.text: Assessee S.K. Mohideen died on April 17, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee died on April 17, 1954 and his son S. K. Habibullah-hereinafter referred to as the respondent-applied to the Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras praying for revision of the orders.

facts.text: Son S.K. Habibullah applied to Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras for revision of orders.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee died on April 17, 1954 and his son S. K. Habibullah-hereinafter referred to as the respondent-applied to the Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras praying for revision of the orders.

facts.text: Commissioner held s.35 properly invoked and rejected applications.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner held that s. 35 was properly invoked for rectification of the assessments and rejected the applications. But the High Court of Judicature at Madras in petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Madras High Court ordered writs of certiorari quashing ITO orders in petitions under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court of Judicature at Madras in petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution filed by the respondent ordered that writs of certiorari do issue quashing the orders of the Income-tax Officer, V Circle.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras appealed to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras appeals to this Court with certificate of fitness granted by the High Court. The plea of the Commissioner that the assessee having assented to the rectification,

facts.text: Assessee's letter dated March 24, 1954 did not assent to unauthorized rectification.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the Commissioner that the assessee having assented to the rectification, it was number open to the respondent to challenge the authority of the Income-tax officer, has numberforce. By his letter dated March 24, 1954 the assessee merely informed the Income-tax officer that he had numberobjection to rectification according to law.

facts.text: Assessments of the two firms were completed before April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The assessments of the two firms were companypleted a long time before April 1, 1952 It is also companymon ground that the individual assessments of the assessee were number provisional but final assessments under 8. 23  3  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Individual assessments were final under s.23(3), not provisional.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon ground that the individual assessments of the assessee were number provisional but final assessments under 8. 23  3  of the Income-tax Act. The question which falls to be companysidered is whether relying upon cl.  5  of s. 35

facts.text: Section 35(5) incorporated by s.19 of Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 with effect from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Income tax Officer, however, sought to rely upon s. 35 5  which was incorporated by s. 19 of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1953  25 of 1953  with effect from April 1, 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: ITO had no jurisdiction under s.35(5) to rectify since firm assessments were before April 1, 1952.

issues.text: whether the assessee having assented to the rectification, it was open to the respondent to challenge the authority of the Income-tax officer

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the Commissioner that the assessee having assented to the rectification, it was not open to the respondent to challenge the authority of the Income-tax officer, has noforce. By his letter dated March 24, 1954 the assessee merely informed the Income-tax officer that he had noobjection to rectification according to law. But if the law did not authorise the Income-tax Officer to rectify the assessment, assent could not validate what was unauthorised.

issues.text: whether a mistake discovered because of something contained in the assessment of the firm is a mistake apparent from the record of assessment of the individual partner

anchor.surface_text: contained in the assessment of the firm is not a mistake apparent from the record of assessment of the individual partner. In Kanumar lapaudi Lakshminarayana Chetty v. First Additionnal Income-tax Officer, Nellore 1  in dealing with the question whether the record of the assessment of the firm may be regarded as the record of the assessment of the individual partner, Subba Rao, C.J. speaking for the Court observed, and, in our Judgment, correctly But it is said that section 35 of the Act even without the amendment would have enabled the Income Tax authorities to reopen the assessment on the ground that there was a Mistake apparent from the record.

The Legislature has given to cl.  5  a partial retrospective operation. The provision enacted by cl.  5  is not procedural in character it affects vested rights of the assessee.

holdings.text: The assessee's assent to rectification does not validate the Income-tax Officer's action if not authorised by law

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the Commissioner that the assessee having assented to the rectification, it was number open to the respondent to challenge the authority of the Income-tax officer, has numberforce. By his letter dated March 24, 1954 the assessee merely informed the Income-tax officer that he had numberobjection to rectification according to law. But if the law did number authorise the Income-tax Officer to rectify the assessment, assent companyld number validate what was unauthorised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The letter expressed no objection to rectification according to law, but assent cannot confer jurisdiction or validate unauthorised rectification

holdings.text: A mistake discovered from the assessment of the firm is not a mistake apparent from the record of the individual partner's assessment

anchor.surface_text: Section 35 1  empowers the income-tax authorities to rectify mistakes apparent from the record of certain orders passed by them. The clause  omiting parts number material  provides that the Income-tax officer may at any time within four years from the date of any assessment order passed by him, on his own motion rectify any mistake apparent from the record of the assessment. The power of rectification may be exercised subject to two companyditions  1  that there is a mistake apparent from the record of the assessment, and  2  that the order of rectification is made within four years from the date of the assessment sought to be rectified. The mistake which may be rectified need number be in the order itself it may be in any part of the record or proceeding of assessment of the assessee. But for the purpose of assessment an individual and a firm are distinct entities and even if an individual is a partner of the firm, a mistake discovered because of something companytained in the assessment of the firm is number a mistake apparent from the record of assessment of the individual partner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Individual and firm are distinct entities; record of firm assessment not part of partner's assessment record; approves Kanumarlapudi precedent

holdings.text: Section 35(1) of the Income-tax Act could not be resorted to for rectification of the assessee's assessments

anchor.surface_text: Section 35 1  of the Income-Tax Act companyld number therefore be resorted to by the Income-tax authorities for rectification of the assessments of the assessee, for there was numbererror apparent from the record of those assessments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No mistake apparent from the record of the partner's assessment; error discovered only from subsequent firm assessment

holdings.text: The provision enacted by clause 5 of section 35 is not merely procedural but affects vested rights of the assessee and has only partial retrospective operation from April 1, 1952

anchor.surface_text: under s. 23 3  of the Income-tax Act. The question which falls to be companysidered is whether relying upon cl. 5  of s. 35 an Income tax Officer may rectify the assessment of a person who is a partner of a firm when the assessment of the firm is completed before the 1st of April, 1952. The Legislature has given to cl.  5  a partial retrospective operation. The provision enacted by cl.  5  is number procedural in character it affects vested rights of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affects finality of assessments which are vested rights; no greater retrospectivity without clear legislative words; cites Privy Council on finality

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer has no jurisdiction under clause 5 of section 35 to rectify the assessment of a partner consequent upon assessment of the firm completed before April 1, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The power to rectify assessment of a partner companysequent upon the assessment of the firm of which he is a partner by including or companyrecting his share of profit or loss can therefore be exercised only in Case of assessment of the firm made on or after April 1, 1952. The Income-tax officer has numberjurisdiction under cl.  5   of s. 35 of the Act to rectify the assessment of a partner of a firm companysequent upon the assessment or reassessment of the firm disclosing an error made before April 1, 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 5 confers new power from April 1, 1952; partial retrospectivity only; distinguishes from clause 6; follows Kandan Lal and Kanumarlapudi; fiction necessary as clause 1 insufficient

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the Commissioner that the assessee having assented to the rectification, it was number open to the respondent to challenge the authority of the Income-tax officer, has numberforce. By his letter dated March 24, 1954 the assessee merely informed the Income-tax officer that he had numberobjection to rectification according to law. But if the law did number authorise the Income-tax Officer to rectify the assessment, assent companyld number validate what was unauthorised.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 35 1  empowers the income-tax authorities to rectify mistakes apparent from the record of certain orders passed by them. The clause  omiting parts number material  provides that the Income-tax officer may at any time within four years from the date of any assessment order passed by him, on his own motion rectify any mistake apparent from the record of the assessment. The power of rectification may be exercised subject to two companyditions  1  that there is a mistake apparent from the record of the assessment, and  2  that the order of rectification is made within four years from the date of the assessment sought to be rectified. The mistake which may be rectified need number be in the order itself it may be in any part of the record or proceeding of assessment of the assessee. But for the purpose of assessment an individual and a firm are distinct entities and even if an individual is a partner of the firm, a mistake discovered because of something companytained in the assessment of the firm is number a mistake apparent from the record of assessment of the individual partner.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

Section 35 1  of the Income-Tax Act companyld number therefore be resorted to by the Income-tax authorities for rectification of the assessments of the assessee, for there was numbererror apparent from the record of those assessments.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

The question which falls to be companysidered is whether relying upon cl. 5  of s. 35 an Income tax Officer may rectify the assessment of a person who is a partner of a firm when the assessment of the firm is completed before the 1st of April, 1952. The Legislature has given to cl.  5  a partial retrospective operation. The provision enacted by cl.  5  is number procedural in character it affects vested rights of the assessee.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.
